channel.title: SXF4J - Simple XML Facade for Java
channel.description:
This is a little something I started on quite awhile back, and recently got into a working state.
https://github.com/moparisthebest/sxf4j
Yes, I stole the naming idea from SLF4J, but since it does basically the same thing for XML that SLF4J does for Logging, it made sense to do. The source code is pretty simple, so take a look and tell me what you think.
Also take a look at ClassXmlElement, which I started from scratch never having looked at XStream, but which turns out has a similar-ish goal. Tell me what you think about that as well, especially how it compares if you have actually used XStream.

item.title: SXF4J - Simple XML Facade for Java
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Most of the time it’s:

root: interfaces, abstract classes and helpers
subdir (impl): implementation of said interfaces/abstract classes

Read full topic
item.source: SXF4J - Simple XML Facade for Java

item.title: SXF4J - Simple XML Facade for Java
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I understand that, it’s just how I did it at the time as it was a proof of concept type thing. Would the package above that be a better location for the interfaces? I’m not sure how most libraries do that actually.

Read full topic
item.source: SXF4J - Simple XML Facade for Java

item.title: SXF4J - Simple XML Facade for Java
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

I think you may be confused as to what “impl”, as a package name, is generally used for. Purely abstract interfaces like XmlElement and XmlElementFactory, for example, are not implementations.

Read full topic
item.source: SXF4J - Simple XML Facade for Java

@moparisthebest wrote:

This is a little something I started on quite awhile back, and recently got into a working state.

GitHub

moparisthebest/sxf4j

sxf4j - Simple XML Facade for Java

Yes, I stole the naming idea from SLF4J, but since it does basically the same thing for XML that SLF4J does for Logging, it made sense to do. The source code is pretty simple, so take a look and tell me what you think.

Also take a look at ClassXmlElement, which I started from scratch never having looked at XStream, but which turns out has a similar-ish goal. Tell me what you think about that as well, especially how it compares if you have actually used XStream.
